subject: Re: Do JUnit internals suck?!?
msgSnippet: ... with ... What would you like to see in the interfaces? For TestCase, I see: int countTestCases() // Makes sense TestResult run() // Utility method, not
messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., Berin Loritsch <bloritsch@a...> wrote:
> How about starting by associating the TestCase/TestSuite contracts
with
> explicit interfaces. That way you strengthen the API, removing
> dependencies on those two classes.

What would you like to see in the interfaces? For TestCase, I see:
int countTestCases() // Makes sense
TestResult run() // Utility method, not general enough for
an interface
run(TestResult result) // Makes sense
runBare() throws Throwable // Used internally
String toString() // Already in Object
String getName() // Makes sense
setName(String name) // Used internally

For TestSuite, I see:
addTest(Test test) // Makes sense for the composite
addTestSuite(Class testClass) // Really belongs in another
class
int countTestCases() // Makes sense
run(TestResult result) // Makes sense
runTest(Test test, TestResult result) // Used internally
Test testAt(int index) // Makes sense for the composite
int testCount() // Used in the tree model
Enumeration tests() // Also used in the tree model
String toString() // Already in Object
setName(String name) // Used internally
String getName() // Makes sense

There is a common interface, which is the same as Test with the
addition of getName(), and there is the possibility of a second
interface to represent a composite of tests.

The compression of fixtures and single test cases into one class is
regrettable, but better than any of the alternatives we explored.
You can still write a single test case per class if you want. In
answer to an earlier comment, an instance of TestCase is always a
leaf, never an interior node in the Composite. The class is used as
a token in building suites, true, but never an instance.

Kent
